DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures End Mixed in Shortened Session
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices finished mixed Friday in a shortened trading session on the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading conditions were thin ahead of the New Year's weekend. The markets closed at noon CST, 75 minutes earlier than usual. Old-crop contracts, those for delivery through next summer, were little changed or lower while manyof the new-crop contracts rose moderately as traders began to think about the 1990 growing season, said Dale Gustafson, an analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Chicago. He said current stocks of grains and soybeans are more than adequate and there is no danger of supply tightness. But any adverse weather beginning next spring could affect next year's crops, Gustafson said. And with this winter starting out as a hard one, some traders already are anticipating crop difficulties in the new year. Wheat futures settled \ cent to 3 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $4.09\ a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.39} a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cents lower with March at $1.53{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents lower to 2{ cents higher with January at $5.68 a bushel.
